title: The diversification of South American murid rodents: evidence from mitochondria1 DNA sequence data for the akodontine tribe
abstract: Phylogenetic relationships based on 801 base pairs (bp) of the mitochondria1 cytochrome b gene are examined for eight genera and 28 species of the akodontine tribe of South American murid rodents. The akodontine tribe comprises some 35% of the total diversity of the subfamily Sigmodontinae, but the current taxonomy at virtually all levels is uncertain because of inadequate generic diagnoses and assessments of variation and trends in traditional morphological characters. Monophyly of the tribe cannot be resolved by the sequence data, based on comparisons to outgroup taxa in three other tribes (Oryzomyini, Phyllotini, and Thomasomyini). However, highly corroborated monophyletic units within the group are obtained in a variety of both parsimony and distance analyses. These include a redefined and numerically dominant genus Akodon (with Microxus and Hypsimys as synonyms), Bolomys, Lcnoxus, Oxymycterus, and a strongly supported assemblage that includes the central Andean Chroeomys and 'Akodon' andinus and the southern Abrothrix, 'Akodon' olivaceus, and the long-clawed mice of the genera Notiomys, Geoxus, and Chelemys. Sequence divergence within species is typically less than 5%, although levels can reach 10% for some highly polytypic forms. Divergence among genera within the tribe reaches 35% in corrected estimates, a level that is as great as that among representatives of different tribes. Changes in the current classification of akodontines are suggested based on these data, and the timing and place of origin of the tribe and its radiation is discussed. ADDITIONAL KEY WORDS:-mtDNAsequence divergence-Akodon-South Americaph ylogene tics. CONTENTS Sigmodontinae), indicating taxa sampled for this study. This arrangement is based on current taxonomy

body_text.text: The extensive numerical and adaptive diversity of South American murid rodents (subfamily Sigmodontinae) has sparked considerable interest in studying the evolutionary history of the group. Controversies have centred on the place of origin of the subfamily, on the areas of major differentiation of its members, and on the timing of lineage diversification (see, for example, Hershkovitz, 1966a; Patterson & Pascual, 1972; Baskin, 1978; Reig, 1980; Marshall, 1979; Simpson, 1980; and Voss, 1988) . Underlying these controversies has been a deep taxonomic confusion which has contributed to difficulties in, and thereby prevention of, an understanding of true relationships within and among the defined lineages of this South American radiation. Some 45-55 genera and about 250 species (Reig, 1980 (Reig, , 1986 (Reig, , 1987 are usually recognized; these are varyingly split into seven or eight suprageneric tribes. Among these, the Akodontini constitute one of the largest, most complex, and taxonomically most poorly understood tribes. Here, we examine phylogenetic relationships among the Voss (1991a) , as well as the distribution of 'Akodon' urichi, which appears to be close to Bolomys based on the mtDNA sequence data described in the text.
akodontines, and between this and other tribes of South American sigmodontines, based on mitochondria1 DNA (mtDNA) sequence data.

The current taxonomic arrangement, combining Akodon Meyen, 1833 and related genera to form the akodontine tribe (based primarily on Reig, 1980 Reig, , 1986 Reig, , 1987 is shown in Table 1 . Eight of the 12 genera in the tribe Akodontini are represented in this study, plus four of the seven subgenera within the genus Akodon. Those that are not included are largely monotypic with limited geographic ranges. In addition, representatives of three other tribes of South American sigmodontine rodents are included as outgroups. Of the four tribes examined, three (akodontines, phyllotines, and oryzomyines) together contain 87% of all the species of South American sigmodontines (Reig, 1986) . To some extent these tribes may be groupings of convenience, and may not represent phylogenetic units, as will be considered in the analyses that follow.

Numerous questions with regard to the monophyletic status of units of lower taxonomic rank also occur within the tribe Akodontini. The species limits of a number of the taxa are poorly understood, and few cladistic analyses of any type of data are available to support the monophyly of most genera in the tribe. Comments on needed specific and generic level revisions within the group will be made, although complete revisions of the taxa are beyond the scope of this report. These must include appropriate treatments of craniodental morphology, soft anatomy, and other morphological and genetical attributes.

Some akodontine genera are quite speciose and have broad geographic distributions, for example Akodon, Bolomys Thomas, 191 6, and Oxyrnycterus Waterhouse, 1837 ( Fig. 1) . Although the akodontines are primarily Andean in distribution (and have been argued to be central Andean in origin [Bianchi et al., 1971; Reig, 1984] ), many species are also widely distributed in temperate, subtropical, and even tropical lowlands. Other genera in the group include only one, or a few species, which have limited distributions ( taxon. Although its range (see the map, Fig. 2 ) implies a reasonable distribution, there are fewer than 10 specimens of this genus known in collections (0. P. Pearson, pers. comm.) . Similarly, the genus Podoxymys Anthony, 1929 is known from a total of six specimens from the Roraima tepui of the Venezuelan-Brazilian-Guyanan border (PCrez-Zapata et al., 1992) ; Juscelinomys Moojen 1965 is known only from three specimens from the Federal District of Brazil; and the recently described Pearsonomys Patterson, 1992 of the austral forests of southern Chile is known only from the type specimen. The possibility of obtaining mtDNA sequences from museum study skins (Smith &Patton, 1991 b) will allow us eventually to include all taxa, even those that are extremely rare, for a complete representation of the tribe.
American sigmodontine rodents. The IUPAC ambiguity code is used at degenerate sites. The Mus numbering refers to the position in the complete mtDNA sequence for the house mouse (Bibb et al., 1981) .
body_text.section: TABLE 2. Primers used for amplification and sequencing of cytochrome b in South

body_text.text: DNA was extracted from frozen liver tissue by using the sodium dodecyl sulphate-proteinase K/phenol/RNAse method (Maniatis et al., 1982) , or by using Chelex (Walsh et al., 1991) . For one individual, only dried skin was available, and for two additional individuals the liver sequence was verified by sequencing from skin extracts as well. Chelex was used for extraction from skins, and the T4 gene 32 protein was added to the PCR reactions to enhance amplification from these extractions (Lessa et al., 1992) .
body_text.section: MATERIALS AND METHODS

body_text.text: DNA sequence was obtained for segments of the cytochrome 6 gene (cyt 6) via the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) using various combinations of primers (Table 2 ; Fig. 3 ). The most common approach used was amplification of double-stranded product for the entire cyt 6 gene using primer MVZ 05 with MVZ 14, followed by single-stranded amplification of two shorter overlapping segments, using primer MVZ 05 with MVZ 04, and primer MVZ 11 with MVZ 16. The limiting primer in the single-stranded reaction was used for sequencing; additional internal sequencing primers were also used. For example, the light strand sequence could be obtained by using MVZ 05 and MVZ 11 as sequencing primers on the single-stranded product obtained with MVZ 05-MVZ 04, and using MVZ 35 (this primer worked best within the genus Akodon) or MVZ 45 (on taxa outside the genus Akodon), plus MVZ 23 as sequencing primers on the single-stranded product obtained with MVZ 11-MVZ 16. Amplification was similar to that described in Smith & Patton (1991a) , on a Techne Programmable Dri-Block PHC-1 machine, with a typical program of denaturation at 93°C for ' 2 min, annealing at 45°C for 1.5 min, and extension at 72°C for 2 min, with 32 cycles for double-stranded and 35 cycles for single-stranded amplification. Sequences were entered into BIONET (IntelliGenetics, Inc., 1988) for alignment and translation. Sequence data were analysed using several software packages. Pairwise comparisons of sequences to get distances, the number of transition and transversion differences by codon position, and the proportions of each base at each codon position were performed on an IBM compatible 386 computer using version 0.01a of the MoSy program written by Christopher A. Meacham. Maximum parsimony analyses were run on a Macintosh I1 fx computer using PAUP 3.0s (Swofford, 1991) . For each of the data sets the shortest tree was found in an heuristic search, using 100 random orders of the taxa with tree bisection-reconnection (TBR) branch swapping. When more than one tree of the shortest length was found, the strict consensus tree is presented here. A separate bootstrap run with 100 replicates was used to produce bootstrap values for the groups identified on the shortest tree. The bootstrap analyses used 10 random orders of input taxa for each bootstrap replication, except for the analysis of the transversion data, where such an approach was not feasible in terms of the amount of time required to run the analysis. This is because the transversion data set has fewer characters and less resolution; in other words, many more equivalent branching patterns that must be considered. Distance-based analyses were run on a SUN Sparc station in PHYLIP 3.4 (Felsenstein, 1991) , using DNADIST to calculate the distance between taxa using the Jukes-Cantor (Jukes & Cantor, 1969) , Kimura 2-parameter (Kimura, 1980) , and maximum likelihood models, and using the NEIGHBOR program to construct neighbour-joining trees (Saitou & Nei, 1987) . The DNAML program in PHYLIP 3.4 was used to evaluate the log likelihood values for different tree topologies, following the approach used by Kishino & Hasegawa ( 1989) . Each of the three codon positions was analysed separately in DNAML in order to take into account the differences in proportions of the four bases at the three codon positions. Six different transition/transversion ratios (20 : 1, 15 : 1, 10 : 1, 2 : 1, and 1 : 1) were tested, and the transition/transversion ratio, k, that maximized the log likelihood values was chosen for each of the three codon positions in the DNAML analyses. The same tree is not necessarily the best tree for all codon positions. Therefore, after the overall best tree was determined based on the best total log likelihood value, pairwise comparisons of trees were run in DNAML for each codon position to determine standard errors relative to the overall best tree. It is the variance which is additive. Thus, the overall standard errors were calculated by taking the square root of the sum of the standard errors squared (M. Hasegawa, pers. comm.). A tree topology differs significantly from the best tree if the 9504, confidence interval (log likelihood value f 1.96 times the standard error) does not include the log likelihood value of the best tree.
body_text.section: MATERIALS AND METHODS

body_text.text: Representatives from three other tribes of South American sigmodontines were used as outgroups in phylogenetic analyses. Because the monophyly of even these tribes has not been firmly established as yet, we also included the published sequences of the Old World murid rodents Mus and Rattus (from Bibb et al., 1981, and Gadaleta et al., 1989 , respectively as additional outgroup taxa.
body_text.section: MATERIALS AND METHODS

body_text.text: Museum catalogue numbers of the voucher specimens for the individuals that were sequenced are from the following collections:
body_text.section: Specimens examined

body_text.text: Sequence data for 801 bp of cyt b were obtained for 107 individuals. Fewer bases were scored from two additional individuals, as follows: Chroeomys jelskii, MVZ 173084, 401 bp; Notiomys edwardsii, MVZ 163066, 291 bp. The first 401 bp of cyt 6 sequence for 39 of the individuals treated in the current analysis were reported in Smith & Patton (1991a) , and are available in GenBank (accession numbers M3569kM357 16) . The additional 400 bp sequenced for this study have been added to these original accession numbers for these individuals. The 801 bp of sequence for an additional 27 individuals are also in Genbank (accession numbers U03524-U03550), thus making available the sequences for the 41 South American taxa used in the broad scale analyses below. Sixty geographic localities were sampled for the current report, as listed above in Specimens examined. Single individuals were sequenced for 17 of these localities and two were sequenced for forty; three, four, and five individuals, respectively, were sequenced for the remaining three localities. Hierarchical levels of variation, from that within populations to that among tribes, are illustrated in Fig. 4 , using corrected sequence divergence values based on Kimura 2-parameter distances (Kimura, 1980). The maximum amount of variation within a local population was 1 .7y0 corrected sequence divergence, as illustrated in the top histogram of Fig. 4 . Individuals from the same locality were almost always most similar to each other. Geographic differentiation among sampled localities within species ranged up to 9.4% sequence divergence. Values between 5% and 10% sequence divergence were found among the geographic samples of Akodon aerosus, A. mollis, A. orophilus, and Chroeomys jelskii, all of which might in fact encompass more than one species. For example, the three highest values (8.5y0, 9.0yo, and 9.4%) were for comparisons among populations of Akodon aerosus from different valley systems on the eastern Andean slopes of Peru; these differ in karyotype and each is likely to be a distinct species (see also Smith & Patton, 1991a; Patton & Smith, 1992) . Geographic representatives of eight other species that were sampled differed by 4.1% or less. However, in no case is the geographic sampling of the species examined anywhere near complete. Thus, greater differences could still be found for some of these taxa. A reduced data set was created based on an initial parsimony analysis of the 107 individuals and 60 localities. In the reduced set, a single individual was used to represent each cluster within a species that had a bootstrap value of 95% or greater in the initial analysis. This set included 41 South American taxa (the 41 individuals are identified by asterisks in the Specimens examined), plus Mus domesticus (Bibb et al., 1981) and Rattus norvegicus (Gadaleta et al., 1989) . The matrix of percent sequence divergence based on Kimura 2-parameter distances among these 43 taxa provides the data for the remaining comparisons in Fig. 4 , and is available upon request from the senior author. The third line in Fig. 4 illustrates the extent of sequence differentiation among species within the genus Akodon, as restricted here based on phylogenetic analyses (see below). The remaining levels in the figure show other groupings relative to this restricted concept of the genus Akodon. Presumed representatives of Bolomys (including 'Akodon' urichi) are grouped closest to Akodon in terms of sequence divergence, followed by Oxymycterus and Lenoxus Thomas, 1909. A clade of genera whose distributions are limited to the central and southern Andes, as identified in the phylogenetic analyses below, is quite distinct from the genus Akodon. There is no overlap between the range of differences within Akodon and that between members of this Andean clade and Akodon. This group of distant akodontine taxa differs from Akodon almost as much as do representatives of other South American tribes of sigmodontines. The final comparison in the parallel histograms is of Akodon with the Old World murids Mus and Rattus, which together constitute the most distant outgroup in our analyses.
body_text.section: Hierarchical Levels of Sequence Divergence

body_text.text: Silent substitutions occur at a higher rate than changes causing amino acid replacements in protein coding sequences of animal mtDNA, and transitions accumulate much more rapidly than transversions (Brown et al., 1982) . Therefore, at different levels in an analysis of mtDNA sequence data, it may be appropriate to emphasize different classes of changes, depending upon the overall degree of sequence divergence. For the reduced summary data set of 43 individuals, all third position changes were silent, and all second position changes caused amino acid replacements. At the first position, all transversions and about half the transitions caused replacement. The 43 by 43 matrix of In c? ?

body_text.section: Base substitutions

body_text.text: The number of third position transitions among akodontine genera can be as high as the number of such changes between akodontines and M u , so these sites are saturated except for very close comparisons. Traditional parsimony analyses can give misleading results if rates of change differ among lineages (Felsenstein, 1981) . Thus, as a crude test for differential rates, the number of differences between Mus or Rattus and the various South American taxa were compared. The number of differences are reasonably uniform, suggesting comparable rates of change in the various South American lineages.
body_text.section: Base substitutions

body_text.text: Parsimony Analyses When the sequences for one individual from every locality were considered, more than half of the sites (422 out of 801) had the same base in Mus and Rattus and in all South American taxa. Of the 379 variable sites, 37 were autapomorphies, leaving 343 phylogenetically informative sites. More detailed analysis that examined relationships within Akodon, Bolomys, and the Andean group of taxa included all sampled localities for these groups.
body_text.section: Phylogenetic hypotheses: major lineages within the Akodontini

body_text.text: Analyses at deeper levels of relationships need to filter out the 'noise' caused by saturation, that is the multiple changes at silent sites that accumulate over the longer time periods. Thus, our analyses outlining the major clades of South American taxa relied only on transversions. For the reduced data set of 43 taxa, there were 187 variable sites when transversions alone were considered. Twenty-three of these were autapomorphies, leaving 164 phylogenetically informative transversions. The distribution of 100 000 random trees based on this data set was significantly skewed [g, = -0.35, P < 0.01 (Hillis & Huelsenbeck, 1992) ; Fig. 51 , suggesting that there is indeed non-random information in the data (Hillis, 1991) . The shortest tree revealed by parsimony analyses (see below) was over 300 steps shorter than that obtained by the random tree generation procedure (647 versus 1038 steps, respectively). This shortest tree differed from the mean of the random distribution by 17 times its standard deviation.
body_text.section: Phylogenetic hypotheses: major lineages within the Akodontini

body_text.text: A parsimony analysis using 100 random orders of the taxa discovered two islands of trees (following Maddison, 1991) ) with all trees of length 647. There are several features common to the strict consensus trees for each of the two islands (compare Fig. 6A with 6B ). In both, bootstrap values of 60% or greater are indicated, based on a separate bootstrap analysis on the transversion data in PAUP with 100 replicates. The bootstrap values here are not intended as exact statistical tests, but rather to give some indication of groupings that have reasonably strong support. The same highly supported clusters of taxa based on the separate bootstrap analysis were found in both consensus trees.
body_text.section: Phylogenetic hypotheses: major lineages within the Akodontini

body_text.text: A group of 18 taxa, representing 14 or more species of Akodon, is consistently identified. Microxus mimus, the type species for the genus (or subgenus) Microxus, clearly falls within the genus Akodon, as noted in Patton et al. (1989) and Smith & Patton (1991a) . Akodon siberiae, allocated to the subgenus Hypsimys (Myers 8z Patton, 1989a) , also fits well within Akodon. All other members of this clade are currently considered members of the nominate subgenus of this very speciose Figure 6 . A, Strict consensus tree for the first of two islands of most-parsimonious trees of length 647 based on the transversion data set for 43 taxa. This island has 96 trees. Circled bootstrap values (60°/, or greater) were derived from a separate bootstrap analysis with 100 replicates. Locality numbers (from Specimens examined) follow the species names. B, Strict consensus tree for the second of two islands of most-parsimonious trees based on the transversion data set for 43 taxa. This island has 60 trees.
body_text.section: Phylogenetic hypotheses: major lineages within the Akodontini

body_text.text: genus. The first branch to join the Akodon clade consists of a sample from southern Venezuela (urichi, usually placed in the genus Akodon) which is joined to Bolomys lasiurus (from Paraguay). The type species of that genus, Bolomys amoenus from the central Andes, joins next. However, the presumed representatives of Bolomys do not form a monophyletic clade relative to either Akodon or other akodontines; the makeup of this genus needs further investigation. Bolomys plus Akodon do form a clade in a high percentage (83%) of the bootstrap runs as well as in both strict consensus trees. A more detailed analysis of all the populations sampled within Akodon and Bolomys is presented below.
body_text.section: Phylogenetic hypotheses: major lineages within the Akodontini

body_text.text: The three species of Oxymycterus that were sampled form a highly corroborated clade, being identified in lOOyo of the bootstrap replicates. Although our representation of this widely distributed genus (Fig. 1) is limited, it does include species that encompass the elevational span of the genus, from the high Andes of Peru to the lowlands of Paraguay. Lenoxus is positioned next to Oxymycterus in all analyses, but these two genera do not form a sister-group relationship, as has been suggested by some authors (Hershkovitz, 1966b; Reig, 1980 Reig, , 1987 .
body_text.section: Phylogenetic hypotheses: major lineages within the Akodontini

body_text.text: A final clade within the akodontines seems at first to be a surprising mixture of taxa; certainly, this grouping has not been identified by previous authors to our knowledge. It includes two taxa that were considered until very recently to be species of Akodon (sens stricto), namely andinus and olivaceus from the central Andes of Peru south to Chile and Argentina. These two group with Chroeomys Thomas, 1916 (from the central Andes) and Abrothrix Waterhouse, 1837 (southern Andes), which have been considered variously as subgenera within the genus Akodon (as in Table 1 ) or, in the case of Abrothrix, as a separate genus related to Oqmycterus (Hershkovitz, 196613) . Finally, included in this group are three other genera from the akodontine tribe, the southern Andean long-clawed mice Chelemys Thomas, 1908 , JVotiomys, and Geoxus Thomas, 1919 (see Pearson, 1984 Patterson, 1992) . This unusual grouping was identified in 1 0 0~o of the bootstrap replicates and in all trees of the two separate minimal length islands. A more detailed discussion of this clade is presented below.
body_text.section: Phylogenetic hypotheses: major lineages within the Akodontini

body_text.text: The two representatives of the thomasomyine tribe, Thomasomyx Coues, 1884 and Rhipidomys Tschudi, 1844, form a sister relationship in the consensus trees of both sets of tree islands, but the bootstrap value for their association is less than 60%. Of the phyllotines, Calomys Waterhouse, 1837 and Auliscomys Osgood, 19 15 group together, but Irenomys Thomas, 1919 is separate. Of the oryzomyines, Nectomys Peters, 1861 and Oryromys Baird, 1857 group together, and Oligoryromys Bangs, 1906 is separate. In the strict consensus tree for the first of two groups of most-parsimonious trees (the island with 96 trees) ( Fig. 6A) , the akodontines do group together before members of the other tribes are added, but the node at the base of the akodontines is not strongly supported. In the strict consensus tree for the second of two groups of most-parsimonious trees (the island with 60 trees) ( Fig. 6B ), Irenomys (a phyllotine) branches out in the middle of the akodontines, and the thomasomyines join the Andean group before that group joins the other akodontines. Thus, with the data currently available, it is not possible to conclude with confidence that the tribe Akodontini is a monophyletic unit (nor, with their limited representation, the other tribes as well). Moreover, it is doubtful if additional sequence data from the cyt b gene will add to the resolution at the base of the sigmodontine radiation; it remains to be seen if other, more conservative gene sequences, might aid in this resolution.
body_text.section: Phylogenetic hypotheses: major lineages within the Akodontini

body_text.text: Relationships among the 43 taxa in the reduced data set were also analysed using a distance-based approach. An assumption of DNADIST is that all sites are included in the analysis, not just the subset of phylogenetically informative sites (Felsenstein, 1991) . Neighbour-joining trees were produced from distance matrices derived from Jukes-Cantor, Kimura 2-parameter, and maximum likelihood models. These matrices are listed in order of increasing complexity of the model. The Jukes-Cantor calculation takes into account differential rates of change at the three codon positions (ratios of 1.0 : 0.3 : 3.1 were used here, based on observed rates in Smith & Patton, 1991a) . The Kimura 2-parameter model accommodates rate differences both for codon position and for transitions versus transversions (a general transition/transversion ratio of 10 : 1 was arbitrarily chosen for these analyses). The maximum likelihood calculation of distance adds the consideration of different frequencies of the four bases (the empirical A : C : G : T ratio of 0.2866 : 0.2935 : 0.131 1 : 0.2888 from the data set was used).
body_text.section: Distance analyses

body_text.text: Although one step more refined than the other models, the maximum likelihood distances here do not distinguish between the base frequencies at the various codon positions. In particular, third positions in protein-coding mitochondria1 genes have a very low proportion of Gs (see, for example, Table 3 for this data set). (Separate frequencies at each codon position are used in the analysis below evaluating log likelihood values for user trees in DNAML.) Nei (1991: 122) recommends using Kimura 2-parameter distances when the Jukes-Cantor distances between different sequences fall between 0.1 and 0.3, and the transition bias is high, as is the case for our data set.
body_text.section: Distance analyses

body_text.text: The neighbour-joining (NJ) tree based on the Kimura 2-parameter model for distances is shown in Fig. 7 . This tree is similar in topology to the strict consensus on the 96-tree island (Fig. 6A) . Here, the akodontine taxa form a monophyletic clade, which is followed successively by the thomasomyines, the phyllotines, and finally the oryzomyines. With the exception of the placement of the phyllotine Irenomys and oryzomyine Oligovzomyus, each of the three latter tribal units appears monophyletic.
body_text.section: Distance analyses

body_text.text: Although a transition/transversion ratio of 10 : 1 was used in generating the distance matrix (thus weighting transversions more heavily in the analysis), enough variation remains to give more resolution within Akodon in the NJ trees than was found in the maximum parsimony transversion consensus trees (Fig, 6A and 6B ). The two major groupings within Akodon in the NJ tree based on Kimura distances (Fig. 7) are also found in the detailed analysis of Akodon and Bolomys discussed below. The NJ trees based on Jukes-Cantor or maximum likelihood distances (neither shown) are identical to that in Fig. 7 in topology for Akodon, Bolomys, Oxymycterus, and Lenoxus. The NJ tree based on maximum likelihood distances differs only in having the thomasomyines join the four genera listed above before the Andean group joins the rest of the akodontines. In the NJ tree based on Jukes-Cantor distances, the phyllotines (except Irenomys) and oryzomyines join the Andean group before that group joins the rest of the akodontines. These differences in topology underscore the inability of the cyt b sequences to resolve relationships at the base of the radiation, not only of the akodontines but of the other members of the Sigmodontinae examined.
body_text.section: Distance analyses

body_text.text: The tree topologies obtained from the various analyses on the reduced ( n = 43) data set were compared by calculating log likelihood values in DNAML. Here the three codon positions were considered separately, each with its empirical nucleotide frequencies. The likelihood values for the three positions are added to obtain the total likelihood value for a tree. Five tree topologies were examined, as follows: tree 1, the consensus tree for the island of 60 trees from the maximum parsimony analysis of transversions (Fig. 6B) , modified by incorporating the detailed branching within Akodon found in Fig. 8 below; tree 2, the consensus tree for the island of 96 trees (Fig. 6A) , modified as in tree 1 to include the detailed branching order within Akodon found in Fig. 8 below; tree 3, the NJ tree based on Jukes-Cantor distances; tree 4, the NJ tree based on Kimura 2-parameter distances (Fig. 7) ; tree 5, the NJ tree based on maximum likelihood distances. In the analysis on first position bases, tree 5 had the best (least negative) log likelihood value (Table 4) . However, none of the other trees was significantly worse. At the second position, tree 3 was best, and tree 2 was significantly worse. At the third position, tree 4 was best, but not significantly so.
body_text.section: Log likelihood tests of tree topologies

body_text.text: For the total analysis, combining all three positions, tree 5 was best in terms of total log likelihood. All of the AlnL and standard error values reported in Table 4 are given relative to tree 5. For example, at the second position tree 3 was actually the best tree, so it has a positive value of AlnL relative to tree 5. Presenting the results in this fashion makes it easier to follow the calculations for the total standard errors relative to tree 5 that are given in the final line of Table 4 . None of the other four trees tested here was significantly worse than tree 5. Thus, in keeping with the comments in the previous section, the differences among the trees, which involve mainly relationships at the base of the tree, cannot be resolved statistically with the current data set.
body_text.section: Log likelihood tests of tree topologies

body_text.text: A more detailed maximum parsimony analysis of Akodon and Bolomys included one individual to represent each geographic locality for all species of these genera examined. All classes of changes were included in this analysis since saturation is less of a problem for more closely related taxa. Three members of the Andean group, 'Akodon' andinus, Chroeomys jelskii, and Geoxus valdivianus were designated as the outgroup. There were 266 phylogenetically informative characters in the parsimony analysis. Two shortest trees of length 1157 were found with 100 random orders of input of the taxa. The strict consensus of these two trees is given in Fig. 8 . The genus Akodon in a restricted sense is strongly supported in this tree, as 100% of the bootstrap runs identified this group of species as monophyletic. One group of species, including Akodon mollis, A . orophilus, A . aerosus, A . torques, A. ( = Microxus) mimus, and A . ( = Hypsimys) Siberia, was found in 84% of the bootstrap runs. This group of species primarily inhabits the forested slops of the Andes extending from Bolivia north through Peru to Ecuador (Fig. 9) . A more detailed discussion of the descriptive morphology, geographic distribution, and habitats of these, and other Peruvian taxa, is given in Patton & Smith (1993) . While this group of species appears highly corroborated, populations currently assigned to given species do not always cluster together. For example, populations of A . mollis from northern Peru form a paraphyletic association with A . torques from southeastern Peru, and neither A . aerosus nor A . orophilus are monophyletic. This group probably represents a relatively recent episode of expansion and speciation in the central Andean highlands, following sequential glacial-interglacial episodes. Resolution of their true phylogene tic relationships may be compromised both by the retention of ancestral polymorphisms and lineage sorting of mitochondria1 haplotypes.
body_text.section: Phylogenetic relationships among Akodon, Bolomys, and the Andean clade

body_text.text: The second apparent clade of Akodon includes a group of taxa widely distributed from high Andean elevations to the scrublands of lowland Bolivia and Paraguay and the pampas of Argentina. However, this assemblage, while grouped in the strict consensus tree (Fig. 8 ) , is not well supported by bootstrap analysis. The group does include members of the informal boliuiensis-group of the high Andean puna grassland (see Myers et al., 1990) . However, only A . puer and A . subfuscus are strongly associated (in 960i, of the bootstrap replicates). Of the other two members of the boliviensis-group, A . juninensis is linked with A. kofordi and with A . cursor from lowland Paraguay before joining the first two members of the goup, while A . boliuiensis joins last to the above listed taxa. Beyond Akodon, Bolomys amoenus, B. lasiurus, and 'Akodon' urichi do not form a monophyletic assemblage relative to other akodontines, although the triad is outside of the genus Akodon, supporting the generic status of Bolomys (see Reig, 1987) .
body_text.section: Phylogenetic relationships among Akodon, Bolomys, and the Andean clade

body_text.text: A more detailed maximum parsimony analysis of the central and southern Andean group also included one individual from each geographic locality, with three species , A . orophilus, A . boliviensis, and B. amoenus as the outgroup. Again, all characters were included, and there were 249 phylogenetically informative ones in the data set. The strict consensus of the two shortest trees (length 673) is shown in Fig. 10. 'Akodon' oliuaceus and 'A. ' andinus were linked in all of the bootstrap runs. Together, these two again form a sister relationship with Abrothrix longifiilis and Chroeomys jelskii in 97% of the replicates. The long-clawed, semi-fossorial mice Chelemys, N o~~o~J s , and Geaxus (following Pearson, 1984, and Patterson, 1992) cluster together here, and all seven taxa were grouped in 1 0 0~o of the bootstrap replicates in the analysis on the transversion data set, as noted above.

body_text.section: Phylogenetic relationships among Akodon, Bolomys, and the Andean clade

body_text.text: The phylogenetic analyses of mtDNA sequence data reported here strongly support a set of relationships among member taxa of the tribe Akodontini. In so doing, these data clarify a very muddied current taxonomy and, by virtue of this clarity, provide us with a less myopic vision of the radiation of the South American sigmodontines. While we do not intend in this paper to redefine the genera of this group of rodents, we comment here on the substantive changes in the taxonomy of the group that seem required based on the sequence data, and provide some support for these changes based on the published literature on morphological and other genetical features. For the moment, we adopt the philosophy wherein taxa must be defined by monophyly (see, for example, Rowe, 1988) . A more comprehensive assessment of generic limits will be forthcoming.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The genus Akodon, the largest and taxonomically most difficult genus in the tribe, can now be restricted to include those species examined herein, and close relatives that future studies will identify as members of this clade. Certainly Microxus does not deserve generic status (see also Patton et al., 1989; Smith & Patton, 1991a) . Similarly, it is not clear that some of the subgenera currently recognized, such as Hypsimys, have validity (others, such as Abrothrix and Chroeomys, have validity but do not have close relationship with Akodon). In all analyses, A. ( = Microxus) mirnus and A. ( = Hypsimys) siberiae fall within a cluster of' species that are members of the nominate subgenus Akodon, rather than being sister-taxa to that group (see Figs 6A and B, 7, and 8) . Additionally, it is clear which species should be excluded from this concept of Akodon. For example, the Andean andinus and olivaceus, placed in Akodon by virtually all prior authors (but see Hershkovitz, 1990b) , cannot be included in that genus based on their highly corroborated phylogenetic relationship with the Andean clade of Abrothrix, Chroeomys, and related long-clawed genera. Similarly, the Venezuelan urichi, also usually considered as a true Akodon, must be excluded.
body_text.section: Clades and genera within the Akodontini Akodon

body_text.text: As redefined by Reig ( 1987) , Bolomys consists of the type species amoenus, from the Altiplano of Peru and Bolivia, and a series of largely scrubland species from the lowlands of Bolivia east through Paraguay, northern Argentina, Uruguay, and central Brazil (see map, Fig. 1 ). Our representation of this genus, as defined by Reig, is limited to the highland amoenus and lowland lasiurus. However, the sequence data, while indicating a close relationship, do not support the monophyly of these two species. Inclusion of sequence data from additional taxa from this complex may provide sufficient characters to resolve their relationships with more security. Certainly, this broader sampling will be necessary to confirm the placement of the Venezuelan urichi, usually considered a species of Akodon, within Bolomys. The inclusion of urichi as a member of this unit is somewhat surprising on distributional grounds as well (see Fig. 1 ). However, Voss (1991a) has recently allocated the eastern Ecuadoran punctulatus to Bolomys, closing an apparent latitudinal as well as habitat gap between urichi and the usual set of taxa included in this genus (Reig, 1987 ; see also the map in Fig. 1 ).
body_text.section: Bolomys

body_text.text: Although this group appears at first to include a strange taxonomic mixture, there are in fact several features common to all of these taxa. Geographically, all occur in the Andes from central Peru south to the southern tip of Argentina and Chile (Fig. 11) . These taxa are similar in their karyotypes; all of them have a diploid number of 5 2 (

body_text.section: Andean clade

body_text.text: x x in these taxa was thought to be due to scattered retention of a primitive karyotype for the entire group (Reig, 1987 and included references) , but now it seems more likely that it is a shared derived character for the group, along with several other characters described below. Spotorno (1986) and Spotorno et al. (1990) studied several presumed members of this same group, including 'Akodon' andinus, ' Akodon' olivaceus, 'Akodon' jelskii, Abrothrix longipilis, Abrothrix sanborni, and Abrothrix xanthorhinus. They noted several characters common to the taxa just listed, as follows: a karyotype with 2n = 52, FN = 59, a telocentric chromosome not larger than 6.6% of the total karyotype length, and two medium metacentric pairs. In addition Spotorno et al. (1990) noted differences in the male reproductive structures, with a reduced or absent distal baculum within an elongated penis, in contrast to the full complex penis in Akodon and Bolomys.
body_text.section: Andean clade

body_text.text: They also proposed one of the species, Abrothrix longipilis, as an example of hormonal heterochrony, in that it may have a neonatal delay in testosterone production which may result in a complex of character changes in features such as reproductive structures and body size. These features make longipilis, which is the type species for the genus Abrothrix, different from other related species, which could have caused some of the past taxonomic confusion within the group. Further evidence in support of the grouping of these taxa comes from protein electrophoretic loci, which link taxa within this group, and the presence of an external parasite in common on several species in the group ( Table 5 ) . Abrothrix is certainly not closely related to Akodon (sensu stricto), and cannot be regarded as a subgenus of a more broadly defined Akodon (as per Reig, 1987: 367 , and many previous authors). Neither can Abrothrix be considered an 'oxymycterine' (sensu Hershkovitz 1966b: 86) ; it clearly has no close phylogenetic relationship with the long-nosed mice of the genus Oxymycterus. Rather, Abrothrix must be considered a genus unto itself, and the only questions that remain involve what else should be included in that generic concept. The limits of this genus now include the species longipilis (the type species for the genus), hershkovitri, illuteus, lanosus, mansoensis, and sanboni, all from central and southern Chile and adjacent Argentina (see Gallardo et Hershkovitz, 1990b: 6 ).
body_text.section: Andean clade

body_text.text: Whether or not this group should be expanded to include 'Akodon' andinus and 'Akodon' olivaceus as well as Chroeomys, as has been suggested by Spotorno et al. (1990) , as these taxa together form a monophyletic assemblage (Fig. lo) , must await future analyses and decisions.
body_text.section: Andean clade

body_text.text: There is considerable debate about the overall pattern and timing of the sigmodontine radiation in South America. Figure 12 proposed by Marshall (1979) , in which the sigmodontine rodents evolved in North America before 7 Myr bp. They then arrived in South America, via waif dispersal across the Bolivar Trough, during a worldwide drop in sea level between 7 and 5 Myr bp. The basal stock was probably a forest form. Grazing forms evolved from that basal stock in savannah-grassland areas of Venezuela, Colombia, and the Guianas. The grassland forms were restricted to that area until about 3.5 Myr bp, at which time glacial cycles begain with their coordinated retraction of forest habitats and expansion of savannah grasslands. Sigmodontine rodents then dispersed southward through a savannah-grassland corridor along the eastern foothills of the Andes, and spread throughout the previously disjunct savannah-grasslands of Bolivia, Argentina, and Brazil. Voss (1991b) on the other hand, emphasizes the differences between the savannah mammal fauna of northern South America and that of the cerrado south of the Amazon, implying that grassland muroid faunas did not migrate readily across Amazonia.
body_text.section: Timing and origin of South American sigmodontines

body_text.text: As far as the timing of the entrance of this group into South America, others (Patterson & Pascual, 1972; Simpson, 1980) have suggested that the group did not reach South America until the establishment of the Panamanian Land Bridge, about 3 Myr ago. The existence of somewhat earlier fossils of the group in South America argues against that timing. A much earlier Miocene entrance has been argued by Reig (1986) and Hershkovitz (1966b Hershkovitz ( , 1972 . This hypothesis, however, is unsupported by corroborating fossil evidence at the present time.
body_text.section: Timing and origin of South American sigmodontines

body_text.text: Another topic of debate is whether one ancestral stock arrived, and then radiated in South America, or whether there was initial differentiation, perhaps at the generic level, in Central America, so that several ancestral types entered South America. Reig (1984) has proposed a scenario in which the ancestral stock, thought to be the oryzomyines, differentiated in northwestern South America and then sent an offshoot to differentiate into the akodontines, probably in the central Andes, where the current diversity of akodontine species is highest (Fig. 13) . In this scenario the akodontines then spread out from the central Andes in several directions.
body_text.section: Timing and origin of South American sigmodontines

body_text.text: It is of interest to see how the molecular data might fit in with the various scenarios that have been proposed. Comparisons were made (Table 6 ) using three different rates of change for third position transversions in cyt b. The first rate is from a data set on mammals (primarily ungulates) by Irwin et al. (1991) of 0.5% per Myr. This rate gives a mean time of divergence for species within the genus Akodon, for example, of about 7 Myr. Times for genera within the akodontine tribe are about 25 Myr, and the akodontines versus the oryzomyines average 35 Myr. These are very old divergence times, pre-dating the first fossils of the group by 20 to 30 million years (see Reig, 1987 , for a general summary of fossil akodontines). The calibration based on the ungulate data set may not be the most appropriate to use. There has been discussion in the literature as to whether the rate of DNA evolution is higher in rodents than within other mammals (see Catzeflis et al., 1992 , for a review). It may be more appropriate to use rodent comparisons for calibrating rates for the South American sigmodontines. Thus, a second approach to determining a rate of change used the date of appearance of Bolomys in the fossil record at 3.55 Myr (Reig, 1987) to date the Akodon-Bolomys split. This gives a rate nearly five times faster than the (1992, and included references) , then the rate of change would be 1.7% per Myr, closer to the estimate based on the 10.3 9.7 10.4 9.7 0.2-3.8 3.8-4.6 0.9-2.0 2.2-1 1.7 7.9-1 1.2 7.3-9.7 7.7-1 1.5 7.9-12.3 7.9-1 3.2 8.8-10.8 9. 3-11.5 8.8-10.6 1.6 3.0 1.1 5.5 6.6 6.1 6.5 6.9 7.3 7.6 7.1 7.6 7.1 0.2-2.8 2.8-3.4 0.7-1.4 1 .&8.6 2.6-8.2 5.3-7.1 0.2-8.4 5.8-9.0 5.8-9.7 6.5-7.9 6.8-8.4 6.5-7.7
body_text.section: Timing and origin of South American sigmodontines

body_text.text: Akodon/Bolomys split. However, there is still some debate about the timing of the MuslRuttus split (see, for example, O'Huigin & Li, 1992). The rate calculations are totally dependent on the fossil dates used for calibration. The approaches to the calculation of divergence times used here probably represent the extremes in possible dates.
body_text.section: Timing and origin of South American sigmodontines

body_text.text: All of the rates in Table 6 lead to divergence times which preclude the arrival of a single ancestral stock for all the South American sigmodontines following the establishment of the Panamanian land bridge. The mtDNA sequence divergences observed would support either differentiation in Central America to the generic level before entry into South America, or the arrival of an ancestral type into South America prior to the Panamanian reconnection. To date, we cannot test these two hypotheses with the fossil record, as no fossils of the appropriate time and geographic areas have been found. The rate estimates based on the available fossil data for murid rodents suggest a higher rate change than in other mammals. The reality of higher rates of change in mtDNA in rodents is argued by Catzeflis et ul. (1992) . Martin and Palumbi (1993)

FIGREF11.text: Primers used in various combinations for amplification and sequencing of 801 bp of the cytochrome b gene in South American sigmodontine rodents.

FIGREF13.text: Neighbour-joining tree based on the Kimura 2-parameter distance matrix for 43 taxa. Locality numbers (from Specimens examined) follow the species names.

FIGREF14.text: Log likelihood (InL) values calculated with DNAML in PHYLIP 3.4 for each codon position separately for five tree topologies based on analyses of a subset of 43 taxa of South American akodontine rodents plus outgroups. The arrangement of the table is similar to that in Kishino & Hasegawa (1989: Table 1). The column labelled n gives the number of nucleotides, and k is the optimal transition/transversion ratio for each codon position. The total InL and AlnL values are the sums of the values at the three codon positions. The total SE is the square root of the sum of the individual standard erron squared. Values of AlnL+SE are given to tree 5.

FIGREF15.text: Strict consensus on two shortest trees of length 1 157 from a detailed maximum parsimony analysis of Akodon and Bolomys, with one individual to represent each locality. Circled bootstrap value (60% or greater) were derived from a separate bootstrap analysis with 100 replicates. Locality numbers (from S'ecimem examined) follow the species names.

FIGREF20.text: Proposed areas of differentiation of the ancestral oryzomyine stock of sigmodontine rodents, and of the akodontine tribe, following Reig (1984); redrawn from his Figure 2. The dotted arrow represents the oryzomyine stock giving rise to the akodontines, and the black arrows illustratr the spread of the akodontines in several directions from their area of differentiation. previous one, leading to divergence times of 1-3 Myr within genera, 5-6 Myr within tribes, and around 7 Myr among tribes. A third approach, based on the MuslRattus split, yields a rate intermediate between the previous two. There are 45 third position transversions between Mus and Rattus in the 801 bp of cyt b. The 45 transversions, divided by 267 third position bases, gives a difference of 16.85%. If the divergence of Mus and Rattus based on the fossil record is taken as about 10 Myr, as in Catzeflis et ai.
